<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 120, 378, 143]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 172, 182, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 195, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[783, 172, 905, 230]]<|/det|>
0625/23 May/June 2025 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 247, 506, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 278, 540, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 338, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 885, 524]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(9.8 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 550, 218, 563]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 506, 89]]<|/det|>
Which quantity can be measured using a ruler?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 136, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 101, 562, 117]]<|/det|>
the distance travelled by a toy train in one second

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 127, 136, 143]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 127, 393, 143]]<|/det|>
the temperature of a toy train

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 152, 136, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 152, 545, 168]]<|/det|>
the time taken for a toy train to travel one metre

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 136, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 177, 353, 193]]<|/det|>
the volume of a toy train

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 222, 101, 238]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 222, 759, 238]]<|/det|>
A car is driven from one town to another town along a road that is not straight.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 252, 759, 268]]<|/det|>
The driver of the car divides the total distance travelled by the total time taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 282, 458, 298]]<|/det|>
Which quantity does the driver calculate?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 136, 328]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 312, 368, 328]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 337, 136, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 337, 390, 353]]<|/det|>
the average speed of the car

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 362, 136, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 362, 384, 378]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 388, 136, 404]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 331, 404]]<|/det|>

<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 433, 747, 449]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 136, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 256, 479]]<|/det|>
acceleration

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 488, 136, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 488, 225, 504]]<|/det|>
distance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 513, 136, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 513, 214, 529]]<|/det|>
speed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 538, 136, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 538, 218, 554]]<|/det|>
velocity

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 584, 101, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 584, 654, 600]]<|/det|>
Students are asked for a statement about the weight of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 614, 400, 630]]<|/det|>
Three of the statements are listed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 644, 624, 660]]<|/det|>
<pre>1 The weight is the quantity of matter in the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 669, 712, 685]]<|/det|>
<pre>2 The weight is the effect of a gravitational field on the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 694, 797, 710]]<|/det|>
<pre>3 The weight is the force of attraction between the object and the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 725, 548, 741]]<|/det|>
<pre>Which statements describe the weight of the object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 754, 136, 770]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 754, 758, 770]]<|/det|>
1, 2 and 3 B 1 and 2 only C 1 and 3 only D 2 and 3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 101, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 559, 89]]<|/det|>
Samples of three different liquids have equal masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 102, 639, 118]]<|/det|>
The volumes of the samples are \(190cm^{3}\), \(200cm^{3}\) and \(235cm^{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 132, 918, 164]]<|/det|>
The liquids are poured into a large measuring cylinder and the liquids form three separate layers because they do not mix.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 178, 892, 194]]<|/det|>
What are the readings on the measuring cylinder at the two boundaries between the samples?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 206, 136, 222]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 206, 325, 222]]<|/det|>
\(190cm^{3}\) and \(390cm^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 231, 136, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 231, 325, 247]]<|/det|>
\(190cm^{3}\) and \(425cm^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 136, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 325, 272]]<|/det|>
\(235cm^{3}\) and \(425cm^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 281, 136, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 281, 325, 297]]<|/det|>
\(235cm^{3}\) and \(435cm^{3}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 328, 101, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 328, 379, 344]]<|/det|>
A car moves along a level road.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 358, 644, 374]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows all of the horizontal forces acting on the car.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[164, 385, 834, 483]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 499, 349, 515]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 528, 358, 544]]<|/det|>
The car is slowing down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 553, 136, 569]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 553, 347, 569]]<|/det|>
The car is speeding up.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 578, 136, 594]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 578, 473, 594]]<|/det|>

<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 709, 89]]<|/det|>
A car is travelling around a circular track at a constant speed, as shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 422, 101, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 422, 746, 438]]<|/det|>
A railway truck of mass 8000 kg moves with a velocity of \(1.0 \text{m/s}\) to the right.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 451, 750, 467]]<|/det|>
It collides with a railway truck of mass \(12 000 \text{kg}\) moving at \(2.0 \text{m/s}\) to the left.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 816, 496]]<|/det|>
The two trucks become joined to each other when they collide and move off together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 574, 526]]<|/det|>
What is the velocity of the two trucks after the collision?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 539, 303, 555]]<|/det|>
<pre>A \(1.6 \text{m/s}\) to the left

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 313, 581]]<|/det|>
<pre>B \(0.80 \text{m/s}\) to the left

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 591, 323, 607]]<|/det|>
<pre>C \(0.80 \text{m/s}\) to the right

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 616, 313, 632]]<|/det|>
<pre>D \(1.6 \text{m/s}\) to the right

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 661, 101, 677]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 661, 620, 677]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 691, 560, 707]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 720, 136, 736]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 720, 218, 736]]<|/det|>
\(15 \text{m/s}\)

<pre>C \(220 \text{m/s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[617, 720, 680, 736]]<|/det|>

distance between the particlesmotion of the particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 276, 103, 292]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 276, 804, 292]]<|/det|>
The particles of a gas in a container of fixed volume gain energy in the kinetic store.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 305, 448, 321]]<|/det|>
Which effect does this have on the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 334, 136, 350]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 334, 640, 350]]<|/det|>
Both the pressure and the temperature of the gas increase.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 136, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 359, 505, 375]]<|/det|>
Only the temperature of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 136, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 384, 666, 400]]<|/det|>
Neither the pressure nor the temperature of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 409, 136, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 409, 475, 425]]<|/det|>
Only the pressure of the gas increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 455, 103, 471]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 455, 752, 471]]<|/det|>
Gas particles exert a pressure when they collide with the walls of a container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 484, 540, 500]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the gas particles is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 514, 136, 530]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 514, 900, 530]]<|/det|>
They experience a change in force, which results in a pressure equal to momentum × area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 548, 136, 564]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 544, 853, 576]]<|/det|>
They experience a change in force, which results in a pressure equal to \(\frac{\text { momentum }}{\text { area }}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 580, 136, 596]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 580, 900, 596]]<|/det|>
They experience a change in momentum, which results in a pressure equal to force × area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 614, 136, 630]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 610, 853, 642]]<|/det|>
They experience a change in momentum, which results in a pressure equal to \(\frac{\text { force }}{\text { area }}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 701, 432, 717]]<|/det|>
An object has a constant temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 731, 348, 747]]<|/det|>

Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 760, 136, 776]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 760, 555, 776]]<|/det|>
There is no energy transfer to or from the object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 473, 88]]<|/det|> Which row correctly describes light waves? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 102, 684, 228]]<|/det|>
wave typedirection of vibration
Alongitudinalparallel to direction of wave travel
Blongitudinalperpendicular to direction of wave travel
Ctransverseparallel to direction of wave travel
Dtransverseperpendicular to direction of wave travel
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 258, 124, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 258, 695, 273]]<|/det|> A narrow beam of light consists of two waves of different wavelengths. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 287, 415, 303]]<|/det|> The beam of light hits a sharp edge. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 317, 529, 333]]<|/det|> Which effect will be seen beyond the sharp edge? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 346, 644, 362]]<|/det|> A Both waves continue along the same straight line as before. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 682, 387]]<|/det|> B Both waves bend sharply and continue along a new straight line. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 397, 184, 413]]<|/det|> C <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 397, 920, 429]]<|/det|> The wave of longer wavelength bends round the sharp edge more than the wave of shorter wavelength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 438, 184, 454]]<|/det|> D <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 438, 920, 471]]<|/det|> The wave of shorter wavelength bends round the sharp edge more than the wave of longer wavelength. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 500, 124, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 500, 536, 515]]<|/det|> An object is placed 30 cm in front of a plane mirror. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 529, 545, 545]]<|/det|> Which statement describes the image of the object? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 558, 136, 574]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 712, 574]]<|/det|> The image is the same size as the object and 30 cm from the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 136, 599]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 583, 712, 599]]<|/det|> The image is the same size as the object and 60 cm from the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 136, 625]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 674, 625]]<|/det|> The image is smaller than the object and 30 cm from the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 634, 136, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 634, 674, 650]]<|/det|> The image is smaller than the object and 60 cm from the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 679, 124, 695]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 679, 783, 695]]<|/det|> Which statement about total internal reflection at a glass–air boundary is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 136, 724]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 708, 760, 724]]<|/det|> The angle of incidence inside the glass must be equal to the critical angle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 733, 136, 749]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 733, 768, 749]]<|/det|> The angle of incidence inside the glass must be less than the critical angle. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 759, 136, 775]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 759, 703, 775]]<|/det|> The critical angle is proportional to the refractive index of the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 784, 136, 800]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 784, 718, 800]]<|/det|> The speed of light in glass must be less than the speed of light in air.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 920, 104]]<|/det|> 
21 What is the speed of radio waves in a vacuum and what is the speed of gamma rays in a vacuum?

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 118, 666, 244]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 118, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 919, 105]]<|/det|> A circuit contains a cell with an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of 2.0 V. The current in the circuit is 2.0 A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 600, 135]]<|/det|> How much energy is transferred by the cell in 2.0 minutes? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 136, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 200, 163]]<|/det|> 2.0 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[283, 147, 360, 163]]<|/det|> B <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[380, 147, 425, 163]]<|/det|> 4.0 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 147, 530, 163]]<|/det|> C <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[553, 147, 600, 163]]<|/det|> 8.0 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 147, 650, 163]]<|/det|> D <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[666, 147, 700, 163]]<|/det|> 480 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 192, 118, 208]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[127, 192, 518, 208]]<|/det|> What is the electromotive force (e.m.f.) of a cell? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 220, 136, 236]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 220, 581, 236]]<|/det|> the charge that passes through the cell per unit time． <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 245, 136, 262]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 245, 728, 262]]<|/det|> the energy supplied per unit charge as charge passes through the cell． <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 271, 136, 287]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 271, 477, 287]]<|/det|> the total charge flowing through the cell． <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 296, 136, 312]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 296, 424, 312]]<|/det|> the total energy stored in the cell． <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 341, 118, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[127, 341, 728, 357]]<|/det|> Four lamps and four switches are connected to a power supply, as shown. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 371, 558, 387]]<|/det|> When all the switches are closed, all the lamps are lit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 667, 417]]<|/det|> When one of the switches is then opened, only one lamp goes out. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 431, 323, 447]]<|/det|> Which switch is opened? <pre>30 The diagram shows a wire moving downwards in a magnetic field between two magnetic poles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 658, 118]]<|/det|>
<pre>There is an induced current in the wire because of the movement.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 132, 529, 148]]<|/det|>
<pre>The induced current produces a force on the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 162, 372, 178]]<|/det|>
<pre>In which direction is this force?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 189, 777, 363]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 118, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>31</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 919, 105]]<|/det|>
When the generator shown rotates, there is an a.c. electromotive force (e.m.f.) across the resistor between points P and Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 555, 135]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows the position of the coil at time \(t=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 858, 165]]<|/det|>
The coil rotates clockwise. At time \(t_{1}\), the coil position is horizontal, as shown in diagram 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 775, 436]]<|/det|>
The graph shows the output e.m.f. between points P and Q plotted against time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 444, 466]]<|/det|>
Which point shows the e.m.f. at time \(t_{1}\) ?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 663, 136, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 663, 686, 679]]<|/det|>
What is the purpose of the split-ring commutator in an electric motor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 692, 136, 708]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 692, 825, 708]]<|/det|>
to ensure that the magnetic field in the motor changes direction every half rotation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 717, 136, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 717, 840, 733]]<|/det|>
to ensure that the magnetic field in the motor stays in the same direction at all times

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 742, 136, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 742, 823, 758]]<|/det|>
to ensure that the turning effect on the motor changes direction every half rotation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 767, 136, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 767, 840, 784]]<|/det|>
to ensure that the turning effect on the motor stays in the same direction at all times

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 118, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 919, 105]]<|/det|>
A beta particle has less mass than an alpha particle, but the speed of a beta particle emitted during radioactive decay is approximately 20 times greater than the speed of an alpha particle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 696, 135]]<|/det|>
<pre>Which statement correctly compares properties of these two particles?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 136, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 147, 920, 179]]<|/det|>
Alpha particles are less penetrating because they have less kinetic energy than beta particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 188, 136, 204]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 188, 919, 220]]<|/det|>
Alpha particles are more penetrating because they have less kinetic energy than beta particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 229, 136, 245]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 229, 903, 245]]<|/det|>
Alpha particles are less ionising because they have more kinetic energy than beta particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 136, 270]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 254, 912, 270]]<|/det|>
Alpha particles are more ionising because they have more kinetic energy than beta particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 299, 118, 315]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 299, 606, 315]]<|/det|>
Which observation provides evidence for the nuclear atom?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 328, 136, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 328, 398, 344]]<|/det|>
attraction of opposite charges

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 354, 136, 370]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 640, 370]]<|/det|>
emission of \(\gamma\)-rays during the decay of a radioactive nuclide

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 136, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 501, 396]]<|/det|>
scattering of \(\alpha\)-particles by a thin metal foil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 406, 136, 422]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 406, 465, 422]]<|/det|>
scattering of \(\gamma\)-rays by a thin metal foil

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 451, 118, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 451, 646, 467]]<|/det|>
Which effect on living things is not caused by ionising radiation?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 480, 136, 496]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 480, 212, 496]]<|/det|>
cancer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 136, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 505, 235, 521]]<|/det|>
cell death

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 530, 136, 546]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 530, 230, 546]]<|/det|>
infection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 136, 571]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 228, 571]]<|/det|>
mutation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 601, 118, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 601, 315, 617]]<|/det|>
Isotope X is radioactive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 631, 475, 647]]<|/det|>
<pre>Which statement about X must be correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 660, 136, 676]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 373, 676]]<|/det|>
A nucleus of X is unstable.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 686, 136, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 686, 313, 702]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 712, 136, 728]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 712, 312, 728]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 738, 136, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 738, 312, 754]]<|/det|>
X emits \(\gamma\)-radiation.

<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[127, 73, 919, 105]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 119, 789, 135]]<|/det|>
<pre>The source is placed close to a detector that is connected to a counter, as shown.

<pre>The average background count rate is 20 counts/minute.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 308, 447, 324]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 337, 136, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 337, 312, 353]]<|/det|>
490 counts/minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 362, 136, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 362, 312, 378]]<|/det|>
500 counts/minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 387, 136, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 387, 312, 403]]<|/det|>
510 counts/minute

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 136, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 312, 428]]<|/det|>
530 counts/minute

<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[127, 459, 847, 475]]<|/det|>
In which direction does the Sun appear to move every day, when viewed from the Earth?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 487, 136, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 487, 256, 503]]<|/det|>
east to west

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 512, 136, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 512, 268, 528]]<|/det|>
north to south

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 136, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 537, 268, 553]]<|/det|>
south to north

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 563, 136, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 563, 256, 579]]<|/det|>
west to east

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 609, 136, 625]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 609, 690, 625]]<|/det|>
A distant galaxy is moving away from the Milky Way at \(4 400 000 m / s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 639, 788, 655]]<|/det|>
<pre>What is the approximate distance between the Milky Way and this distant galaxy?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 667, 136, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 665, 740, 683]]<|/det|>
\[
\begin{array}{lllll}
2 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{~m} & \quad \mathbf{B} & 5 \times 10^{11} \mathrm{~m} & \quad \mathbf{C} & 2 \times 10^{24} \mathrm{~m} & \quad \mathbf{D} & 5 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~m}
\end{array}
\]
